A good method section describes what you did in the lab so that it is easy to understand and detailed enough to be repeated. Follow the following guidelines to improve your methods: If your methods are not easy to follow, you can ask someone to read it. Ask him or her to identify places in the procedure that are not clear, and then review those places for more clarity. It may be more helpful to include words that help the reader follow the process of the experiment: step 1, step 2, step 3; first, then, finally; first, second, third; after, next, later, next; etc. If your method is difficult to follow because it is long and complicated, then consider splitting it into separate sections with each a subtitle. You can divide it into the typical parts of an experimental procedure (such as laboratory construction, laboratory procedures, and data analysis) or, if there were multiple experiments, one part for each experimental procedure. If you need to add more details to your methods, go back to the lab manual and to the notes you or a laboratory partner made during the procedure, and use them to remember what you did in the laboratory.

In order to improve the validity of the results, it is necessary to repeat the experiences (at least three) and to assess the influence of external factors such as temperature and humidity. According to the data obtained in the experiment, the sample A has greater stretchability and the sample C has pullable properties.
